contentrichtext.text: {{about|the medieval town and castle in Brittany, France|the modern folly in Omaha, USA|Joslyn Castle}} {{Portal|Brittany}} {{Infobox French commune |name = Josselin |native name = Josilin |image = JosselinCJW1.jpg |caption = View of [[Josselin Castle]] from the [[Oust|River Oust]] |longitude =-2.5472 |latitude =47.9567 |region = [[Brittany]] |department = [[Morbihan]] |arrondissement = Pontivy |canton = Josselin |INSEE = 56091 |postal code = 56120 |mayor = Joseph Seveno |term = 2008—2014 |intercommunality = Pays de Josselin |elevation m = 30 |elevation min m = 32 |elevation max m = 93 |area km2 = 4.48 |population = 2419 |population date = 1999 }} '''Josselin''' ({{Lang-br|Josilin}}) is a [[Communes of France|commune]] in the [[Morbihan]] [[Departments of France|department]] in [[Brittany (administrative region)|Brittany]] in north-western France. ==History== [[File:Banner of the Breton French.svg|200px|left|thumb|Banner attributed to [[Breton people|Breton]] and French Knights at the [[Combat of the Thirty]] in 1351.]] [[St Meriadek]] is said to have founded a chapel there during the 4th century. It became a stronghold of the [[House of Rohan]]. In 1351, during the [[Breton War of Succession]] (part of the Hundred Years' War), two groups of approximately 30 English knights (led by Robert Bramborough, the English captain of Ploërmel) and Franco-Breton knights (commanded by [[Jean de Beaumanoir]], captain of Josselin) staged an arranged combat at a spot halfway between the Chateau de Josselin and [[Ploërmel]]. The Franco-Breton side eventually won after killing or capturing the English force, including Bramborough. This episode was later known as the [[Combat of the Thirty]]. The [[Josselin Castle|Castle of Josselin]] can still be seen today, although only four of the original nine towers remain after the [[Cardinal Richelieu]] ordered the castle partially demolished in 1629. ==Demographics== Inhabitants of Josselin are called ''Josselinais''. ==Breton language== In 2008, 16.05% of children attended the bilingual schools in primary education.<ref>{{Fr icon}} ''Ofis ar Brezhoneg'': [http://www.ofis-bzh.org/fr/services/observatoire/travaux.php?travail_id=83 ''Enseignement bilingue'']</ref> ==Twin towns== It is twinned with two towns: [[Alzey]], Germany and [[Tard]], Hungary. ==See also== *[[Communes of the Morbihan department]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.maires56.asso.fr Mayors of Morbihan Association] {{Fr icon}} * [http://www.insee.fr/fr/methodes/nomenclatures/cog/fichecommunale.asp?codedep=56&codecom=091 INSEE commune file] ==External links== * [http://www.josselin.com Official site] {{Fr icon}} * [http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/merimee_fr?ACTION=CHERCHER&FIELD_98=INSEE&VALUE_98=56091 French Ministry of Culture list for Josselin] {{Fr icon}} * [http://www.viamichelin.co.uk/viamichelin/gbr/dyn/controller/mapPerformPage?strAddress=&strCP=56120&strLocation=Josselin&strCountry=1424&image2.x=28&image2.y=7 Map of Josselin on Michelin] {{en icon}} {{Commons category|Josselin}} {{Morbihan communes}} [[Category:Communes of Morbihan]] {{Morbihan-geo-stub}}
